courseDescription: Preparation, delivery, and analysis of types of speeches with emphasis on extemporaneous speaking.
An introduction to the analysis and practice of effective voice and articulation.   Applications across various communication contexts, such as public communication, media, and social communication.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting communication style based on audience

courseDescription: An introduction to concepts, processes, and effects of communication in personal and social relationships.  Emphasis on fundamental communication skills necessary for the formation and maintenance of relationships.

A study of selected topics designed for non-majors, or for elective credit within a major.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in a booklet distributed to all academic advisors.

A study of selected topics designed for non-majors, or for elective credit within a major.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in a booklet distributed to all academic advisors.
An introduction to the discipline and methods of human communication.  Survey of the major approaches to studying communication across the range of human communication contexts and functions.
Fundamentals of construction, lighting, and production techniques in contemporary theatre and film.  Students will apply acquired skills to active productions for ODU Theatre and Film productions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Construction techniques in theatre and film
Production technology applications in theatre and film
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with production team members
Coordination with ODU Theatre and Film staff
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization of production resources and materials

courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College.  An introduction to the discipline and methods of human communication. Survey of the major approaches to studying communication across the range of human communication contexts and functions.
An introduction to principles, methods, and materials used in designing stage and film productions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of design software (e.g., Adobe Creative Suite)
Understanding of stage and film production equipment and materials
Digital rendering skills for set design
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with directors and production team members
Effective communication of design ideas to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of design options for productions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for set design timelines
Leadership in coordinating production design elements

courseDescription: An examination of mass communication--books, newspapers, magazines, radio, TV, film, sound recordings, and the Internet--as a global institution, industry, and social force.  Media literacy skills are emphasized, as are matters of technology, content, economics, history and impact.

This online course will introduce students to the process of making movies. Students will learn basic conceptual and technical principles of the filmmaking process using personal equipment, such as an iPhone. The course is intended for non-cinema majors and does not satisfy the prerequisite requirement for higher-level production courses.
Technical and Digital Skills: Operational knowledge of personal filming equipment (e.g., iPhone)
Editing software proficiency (e.g., iMovie, Adobe Premiere)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members on film projects
Receiving and providing constructive feedback on film projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of visual storytelling techniques
Adapting to unexpected challenges during filming
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for meeting filming deadlines
Providing clear direction to actors and crew on set

courseDescription: This class focuses on both contextual and close text analysis of masterworks as they have influenced film art and industry.  Students in this course are expected to develop basic research, communication, viewing and critical thinking skills as they apply their knowledge to the analysis of the film experience.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of film art and industry impact

courseDescription: This course will introduce the beginning student to making movies. Students will learn the basics of working with cameras, lights, sound recording, video editing and post production.  This is a hands-on production course and the required prerequisite to most higher-level production courses. Students who complete COMM 271 cannot enroll in COMM 269 and have that course count toward their major.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Giving and receiving feedback on film projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of film content and quality

courseDescription: Digital literacy refers to the unequal understanding people have about how digital technologies work, how that work is regulated, and how digital technologies are used - by us and by others - as effective and strategic communication and information tools. This course offers students a pathway to become digitally literate by teaching them how the work they perform on digital platforms impacts their interpersonal, communal, and social interactions as consumers, citizens, and content producers.
Technical and Digital Skills: Effective use of digital technologies for communication and information
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Impact analysis of digital work on society

courseDescription: Advertising influences consumer beliefs and decision-making. This course introduces students to fundamental concepts in advertising and consumer culture while developing skills and knowledge in information and digital literacy. Topics covered include consumerism and resistance, representation in advertising, audience segmentation, and digital advertising. As they learn to critically evaluate and analyze advertising and its audiences, students will practice message evaluation and research skills. Students will also consider legal and ethical use of information in advertising.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Legal and ethical considerations in advertising

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to the entertainment industry including working methods, processes, and equipment for live, recorded, and interactive entertainment. The exploration will include theatre, opera, dance, concert productions, theme parks, themed-retail, film production, immersive, interactive and virtual environments, and gaming technology. Attention is given to the positive and negative aspects of entertainment technologies and how they impact culture and society.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with team members and stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying positive and negative impacts of entertainment technologies on culture and society
Troubleshooting equipment issues in live entertainment settings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team in various entertainment productions

courseDescription: A study of selected topics designed for nonmajors or for elective credit within a major. These courses will  appear in the course schedule  and will be more fully described by academic advisors.

This survey course introduces students to critical methodologies utilized in the study of media texts.  Through case studies and hands-on exercises, students will learn how to study the production, consumption, and engagement with popular culture and how to decode its meanings.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting findings from media text analysis

courseDescription: An introduction to communication research from a social science perspective.  Experiment, survey, content analysis and observational approaches are covered.  Students learn statistical data collection and data analysis techniques.
A study of interactions within and among communication workplaces and the public.  Attention is given to the media, promotions, community relations, and public information.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading communication teams towards common goals

courseDescription: An analysis and expression of professional speeches, delivered in public, business and special occasion contexts.  Attention is given to audience analysis, library research, development of arguments/evidence as content, creation and use of professional visual aids, expression of appropriate verbal and nonverbal speech cues, speaker credibility, and extemporaneous delivery skills.
Technical and Digital Skills: Recording and editing speeches for online platforms
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Building speaker credibility through speech delivery

courseDescription: This course is an examination of both the theory and practice of communication in the professional setting. Content includes communication theory, work-life  communication, as well as the roles of interpersonal, organizational, and mediated communication as related to the workplace.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to use communication software effectively
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective verbal communication in a professional setting
Conflict resolution techniques in workplace interactions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing communication patterns for improved efficiency
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Delegating tasks in a work environment

courseDescription: This course provides students with an historic overview of films from a variety of European countries.  Students gain the vocabulary necessary to analyze individual films and for the comparative analysis of films from different cultural and historical contexts.  The course will focus on issues such as national and individual identity, film as aesthetic form, gender and sexuality, and popular culture.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of comparative film analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparative analysis of films from different cultural contexts
Critical evaluation of film aesthetics and themes

courseDescription: This writing-intensive course will provide students with a concrete, real-world strategic communications experience in writing for various media to enhance the communication program of an organization. Students will research and write for print, broadcast, social, and digital media like video and electronic newsletters.
Technical and Digital Skills: Writing for print and broadcast media
Writing for social and digital media
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting writing style for different media platforms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating effectiveness of written content for different media channels
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating with different teams for content creation

courseDescription: Companies and organizations from just about every sector have a person or in some cases entire offices tasked with media relations. This course will take an in-depth look at the evolving landscape of multimedia communications, including seismic changes in the media in general, the rise of bloggers, influencers, and other shared media models, and the increasing role that content generation plays in traditional media relations. The course will include hands-on instruction and projects in content generation, media pitching and contact lists, media interviews, press conferences, as well as non-traditional earned media practices.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Building relationships with influencers and bloggers

courseDescription: This course emphasizes a multi-disciplinary and multi-media approach to problem solving. Students will prepare a strategic communication campaign on behalf of a real client. It will include the production of research, strategy, and media material for use by the client. These materials, in turn, may be used in student portfolios as examples of professional capabilities.

This course provides students skills needed to enter the workforce with a robust set of domain-specific skills, which includes practicing those skills in a realistic, hands-on setting, so they feel more ready to win and succeed in jobs in the competitive, modern marketplace. This course will provide relevant skills training to strategic communication students, while fortifying these students for professional success.

An introduction to the theories, processes and effects of communication in nonverbal codes.  Topics include kinesics, proxemics and paralanguage.  Critical analysis and contemporary research emphasized.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of nonverbal communication research

courseDescription: An overview of communication theory and research examining gendered verbal and nonverbal communication.  Topics include communication differences as a function of gender, theories that seek to explain these differences, and critical examination of social practices that create gender prescriptions. This is a writing intensive course.

courseTitle: Production Management for Television and Stage
courseDescription: This course assists students in understanding the elements of production management both in television and on stage.  The course emphasizes organizational and communication skills; technical production knowledge; professional rehearsal and performance protocol according to the rules of AEA, AFTRA and SAG as well as basic production budgeting and scheduling.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Performance protocol according to AEA, AFTRA, and SAG rules

courseDescription: The course covers the systematic process of organizational assessment from basic communication channels (verbal, printed, and electronic modes of communication), to interpersonal and group communication, to the management of events and staff.  This course examines the importance of leadership roles within organizations in planning any event as well as the communication dynamics between management and those being supervised.

courseTitle: Sound Design for Stage and Camera
courseDescription: This class introduces the concepts and techniques of sound design and sound effects for the stage and camera.  Students learn design of sound elements in both a live and recorded environment as well as learn the current equipment and software in digital sound reproduction.

An introduction to the study of communication in task groups.  Course reviews foundational literature and emphasizes communication competencies relevant to optimizing group outcomes including group observation, participation, assessment, and leadership.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Optimizing group outcomes through effective communication strategies

courseDescription: This course builds upon the principles taught in Screenwriting 1 (or equivalent) using the short script as a basis for the exploration.  Utilizing concepts of characterization, plot, dialogue and narrative style, students should complete the course with several production-ready short scripts.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Giving and receiving constructive feedback on scripts
Collaborating with others on script development

courseDescription: An overview of the rhetorical and social scientific theories and research  about persuasion and applications in speeches and campaigns.
Technical and Digital Skills: Applying social scientific research in persuasion
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging audience through effective communication strategies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the impact of persuasive messages

courseDescription: This screenwriting course explores the ways teleplays, stage plays, and screenplays can be crafted using a variety of primary source materials. Through multiple screenings, writing exercises, and deep reading, it examines what constitutes an adaptable piece of prose and how that material can be transformed. Primary weight is given to the movement from novel to film.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding primary source materials in writing
Crafting teleplays, stage plays, and screenplays
Transforming material from novel to film
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective collaboration with writers and directors
Giving and receiving constructive feedback on adaptations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of source material for adaptation
Identifying key elements for successful adaptation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading adaptation projects from novel to film
Managing timelines and deadlines for screenplay development

courseDescription: With the goal of being able to critique a communication event, students study a variety of rhetorical approaches that may include neo-Aristotelian, generic, feminist, metaphoric, fantasy theme, and pentadic approaches to rhetorical criticism. This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of rhetorical approaches (e.g., neo-Aristotelian, feminist, metaphoric)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Critique and provide feedback on communication events
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking in critiquing communication events

courseDescription: In this course, students learn how to transform casual expressions of opinion about celebrities and media into polished reviews and articles worthy of publication in newspapers, magazines, and online platforms. Students will examine models of good entertainment journalism, past and present, in print, on the Web and in podcasts. In particular, students will consider critical reviews, profiles of artists and entertainers, interviews, and trend stories.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using content management systems for publishing articles
Utilizing social media platforms for promotion
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Conducting interviews with artists and entertainers
Crafting engaging headlines and article titles to attract readers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critically analyzing reviews and profiles for improvement
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating with editors and publishers for feedback
Leading a team of writers for collaborative projects

courseDescription: This course examines the basic ways in which the mass media intersect with the currents of contemporary culture.  Both historical and critical approaches to the study of mass communication and popular culture trace the full implications of their mutual determination and interdependence.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of mass media on society

courseTitle: Lighting Design for Stage and Film
courseDescription: This is a production course introducing students to the world of light and shadow, mood and composition by surveying lighting design, its technologies for stage and camera, and such principles as basic electrical theory and stage/studio/location design aesthetics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of lighting technologies for stage and camera
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with directors and other production team members
Effective communication of lighting design ideas and concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing mood and composition through lighting design
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in coordinating lighting design aspects with other production elements
Organizing lighting equipment and resources efficiently for productions

courseDescription: This course serves as an introduction to the art of video post-production. Students explore the theory and practice of various editing styles in order to gain a better understanding of how stories are constructed in the editing room. The course covers principles of post-production of narrative, documentary, and experimental films. Through demonstrations and hands-on experience, students learn editing techniques with an in-depth examination of tools and approaches in a non-linear editing system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of editing tools and approaches
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Feedback integration from peers and instructors

courseDescription: This course provides students with an overview of a range of media industries, exploring their histories and structures and their impact on contemporary media production. Students will track ongoing industry developments, applying course concepts and learning how media is made and how that process is restricted by a range of social, cultural, political, and economic forces.
Technical and Digital Skills: Awareness of social, cultural, political, and economic influences on media production
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of media impact on society
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on media industry topics

courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to the major theories and perspectives that inform the ways media audiences are made meaningful to the creation, distribution, promotion, regulation, and evaluation of media and popular culture.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of media research findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of media audience data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination for media analysis projects

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to narrative screenwriting focusing on the traditional feature film. Students will study screenwriting principles through text reading, film viewing, script analysis and substantial writing assignments. Focus is on story structure, character development, action, dialogue, and proper screenplay format.
This course examines the process of building characters for the camera, and the ways in which the conventions of the stage are adapted for the film or video audience.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting performance for different audience mediums
Collaborating with directors and crew members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adjusting performance based on director feedback
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Taking on leadership roles within scenes
Coordinating with other actors for ensemble scenes

courseTitle: Costume Design for Stage and Camera
courseDescription: This course explores the design aesthetic, historical context, and contemporary impact on performance of the costume garment and its accessories.  Students explore the application of design principles in a practical experience.
Technical and Digital Skills: Design software proficiency (e.g., Adobe Creative Suite)
Knowledge of fabrics and materials for costume construction
Understanding of lighting and color theory for stage and camera
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with directors and other production team members
Effective communication of design ideas to stakeholders
Ability to receive and incorporate feedback on designs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting designs to fit budget constraints
Analyzing historical costume trends for inspiration in design
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for costume production schedules
Team coordination for costume fittings and alterations
Decision-making in selecting appropriate costumes for characters

courseDescription: Focuses on communication theory, research, and applications of a variety of forms of communication in organizational relationships.  Topics include superior-subordinate communication, interviewing, and presentations with an emphasis on a diversity of perspectives and types of organizations.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing interpersonal relationships in a team setting

courseDescription: This is a project oriented, studio class that will focus on the art of animated storytelling from the traditional perspective of stop motion animation combined with digital post production. Students will engage in individual research, writing, storyboarding, editing, and sound creation to produce original short animations.  Crosslisted with THEA 353.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Troubleshooting technical issues in animation production

courseTitle: Drafting and Rendering for Stage and Screen
courseDescription: This course is an intermediate level course designed to introduce the student to the fundementals of graphic skills necessary for the implementation of a scenic design on either the stage or in front of a lens. Techinques and skills will be demonstrated in drafting (hand and computer generated) and perspective sketching and rendering. Crosslisted with THEA 354.

Focuses on critical analysis of theory and research organizations as functional communication systems at the individual, dyadic, small group, and organizational levels.  Topics include information processing, problem solving, impression management, compliance gaining, and network analysis.
This is a project-oriented studio class that will focus on the art of animated storytelling through the use of computer-based 3D animation.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Collaborating with team members on animation projects

courseDescription: This is a project-oriented studio class that will focus on the art of animated storytelling from the perspective of computer-based 3D animation, building on the skills developed in 3D Animation 1. Students will engage in individual research, writing, storyboarding, editing, and sound creation to produce original short animations.

This course will introduce students to color workflow in the digital cinema environment. The focus will be on working with color beginning with the camera, through color correction to delivery, mixing software-specific techniques with a deepening understanding of the underlying theories of color theory and practice. Students will learn and apply industry standard best practices in the field of visual post-production. This is a hands-on workshop style post-production course.

This course will develop design principles and craft techniques to create a wide variety of costume crafts. The course will focus on individual research, design elements and technical challenges. Projects will encourage students to explore textile modification, various applications for clothing design, costume crafts and art materials. Cross-listed with THEA 355.
Technical and Digital Skills: Art materials usage for costume crafts

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students with an in-depth knowledge of the theory of film editing and concepts in film editing such as pacing, rhythm, juxtaposition, and color. The course will encourage students to investigate and understand the effectiveness of various editing techniques deployed by film editors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding pacing and rhythm in editing
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective feedback delivery on editing choices
Collaboration with directors and other team members on editing decisions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effectiveness of editing techniques in conveying emotions or themes
Identifying and resolving continuity errors in editing
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Providing direction to junior editors on editing concepts and techniques

courseDescription: This class focuses on media literacy and on the role of media in society. Students learn and practice elements of news writing, including writing leads, organizing stories, reporting techniques, and interviewing. Story assignments come from handouts, press releases, press conferences, speeches, and public meetings. Some assignments are completed under simulated deadline pressure in the computer lab.

Available for pass/fail grading only.  Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and Career Development Services prior to the semester in which the work experience takes place.  May be repeated for credit.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with supervisors and team members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of work experience tasks and projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for balancing academic and work responsibilities

courseDescription: A structured work experience with or without remuneration, in an appropriately related disciplinary field. An ePortfolio, 150 hours of site work, plus satisfactory evaluations by supervisor and cooperating faculty member are required. Available for pass/fail grading only. Available to Communication, Theatre, and Dance majors and minors only. Cross-listed with DANC 368 and THEA 368.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with supervisors and faculty
Team collaboration in a work setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to new challenges in the workplace
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Working independently and as part of a team

courseDescription: A structured research experience, under the supervision of communication faculty member.  A paper evaluating/analyzing the research, a log of research progress, and satisfactory evaluation by the supervising faculty are required.

Introduction to new media practices and theories.  Focuses upon the powers of composition, networked communities, information management, social networking and identification in digital environments.  Students will examine practical applications such as blogging, online mapping and tagging, online collaborative work such as wikis and self composition in online social networks.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of information in digital environments
Identifying trends in new media practices

courseDescription: This course explores the basic process of producing television from script to presentation.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with crew and talent
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to unexpected changes during production

courseDescription: This course offers the student an opportunity to explore the world of documentary filmmaking. Students will perform research to develop evidence in support of a thesis, then utilize the camera to capture a narrative story based on the thesis. Through this process, the student is better able to understand documentary filmmaking. Students will develop and deliver short documentary films by the end of the semester.

courseTitle: Reporting News for Television and Digital Media
courseDescription: This course focuses on writing for television news and producing online news reports.  Students will strengthen their journalistic skills and learn the importance of writing clearly for a viewing audience while working under newsroom deadlines.  By the end of the course, students should feel confident in producing accurate, detailed reports for television news and online news sites.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear writing for a viewing audience
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Producing accurate reports for television news and online news sites

courseDescription: This course is designed as a practical guide for directors to elicit strong performances from the actors who tell their stories. The class will establish vocabulary and practice techniques that are equally applicable to work in film or theatre. Ideally, the course will encourage students to think beyond genre as they create work that is both dramatically and humanly compelling.
Technical and Digital Skills: Editing techniques for film or theatre
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of vision to cast and crew
Building rapport with actors to enhance performances
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Troubleshooting technical issues during filming or rehearsals
Adapting to unexpected changes in the production
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively during rehearsals and filming
Motivating and inspiring actors to deliver their best performances

courseDescription: Introduces students to cinematography. The course explores camera technique, blocking actors, lighting, and cinematography fundamentals. The concepts of the course are applied to fiction and nonfiction cinema. This is a production class.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with actors and crew members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting visual impact of shots
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Directing and guiding actors and crew members towards a common vision

courseDescription: This course builds on the fundamentals learned in Post-Production I, exploring advanced post-production techniques in picture editing, color correction and grading, sound editing and mixing, VFX editing, title and graphics editing, chroma key and compositing. The focus will be on mixing software-specific techniques with deepening understanding of the underlying theories of editing, color theory and principles of sound post-production. The students will learn and apply industry standard best practices in the field of audiovisual post-production. This is a hands-on workshop style post-production course.

This course is designed to provide students with an introduction to the reporting, writing, and production aspects of a television news program.  Students will learn how to create 15- and 30-minute news broadcasts by developing story ideas and news gathering. Students will also learn the intricacies of shooting and editing video along with the production process involved in recording a live news broadcast.  Each student will spend time both in front of and behind the television studio cameras.  The goal of this course is to produce weekly news programs worthy of broadcast on local television. Students will assume the roles of reporter, writer, producer, floor director, photojournalist, videographer, technician, and more.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear and concise writing for news scripts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Taking initiative in news story development

courseDescription: This course is designed to develop within students a heightened and multifaceted awareness and appreciation for aesthetics of a particular type - motion picture aesthetics. Aesthetic considerations impact us intellectually, emotionally, psychologically, and viscerally. Professionals most definitely employ a language to filmmaking. One must learn the language of motion picture production and aesthetic design in order to convey concepts to their audiences.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Providing constructive feedback on film projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing film scenes for visual impact
Identifying pacing issues in film narratives
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Collaborating with a film crew to achieve a cohesive vision

courseTitle: Sound Recording and Mixing for Film
courseDescription: This course will explore the best concepts in recording, editing and mixing audio for film and post-production. Students will be using Pro Tools hands-on to sync and mix audio to picture. Topics will include location audio, sound design, ADR, mixing, and more.
Technical and Digital Skills: Mixing audio to sync with picture
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating effectively with directors and producers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and resolving sound quality problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing audio files and projects efficiently
Leading the sound recording and mixing process

courseDescription: A study of selected topics designed for non-majors, or for elective credit within a major.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

A study of selected topics designed for nonmajors, or for elective credit within a major.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

This course is designed to introduce students to the study of communication in cultural contexts, the purpose of which is to prepare one to live and work within an increasingly multicultural world.  This is accomplished by defining and critically analyzing concepts of culture.  Throughout the semester, the course will investigate theories of culture and communication that address the development of cultural identity, intercultural communication competence, the role of verbal and nonverbal communication across cultures, the cultural composition of the U.S., and ethical communication and challenge in a globalized era.  This is a writing intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ethical communication in a globalized era
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Verbal and nonverbal communication evaluation across cultures

courseDescription: An overview of general and contextual theories of communication.  Focus is on the nature of communication theory, the role of theory in communication inquiry, and the relationships among theory, research, and practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding general and contextual theories of communication
Applying communication theory to practical situations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in meaningful discussions about communication theory
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the relationships among theory, research, and practice in communication
Critically evaluating communication theories and their applications
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and presenting research findings related to communication theory

courseDescription: This course introduces students to the basic elements of public relations as it pertains to assisting organizations avoid, mitigate and recover from crisis situations.  Students will have the opportunity to both observe and participate in crisis communications situations.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing multiple communication channels during a crisis

courseDescription: This course introduces students to the multi-layered challenges associated with communication in the event of accidents, crises and natural disasters. In addition to incorporating basic elements of public relations as it pertains to assisting organizations avoid, mitigate and recover from external crisis situations, students will have the opportunity to both observe and participate in crafting multi-agency responses to these unplanned events.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Participation in crafting responses to crises
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Mitigation and recovery planning for external crises
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Assisting organizations in crisis avoidance and recovery

courseTitle: Communication and Culture in the Middle East
courseDescription: The course examines the tensions between modernity and tradition in the context of Middle East culture.  Cultural variables for study include myth and religion, family structures and the use of science and technology.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding cultural variables in Middle East
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying tensions between modernity and tradition

courseDescription: This course provides an overview of contemporary scholarship on phenomena within the scope of interpersonal health communication. Students will become familiar with fundamental communication processes that are involved in the interprofessional management of physical and mental health. Additionally, students will develop an awareness of how communication among friends, family members, professionals, and others influences people's well-being, and how, in turn, health and illness shape communication and relationship dynamics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of communication platforms and tools
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of health communication strategies
Analyzing communication dynamics in health contexts
Identifying barriers to effective health communication
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination in health communication projects
Organizing communication campaigns for health promotion

courseDescription: A survey of classic and contemporary theories and research of communication in personal and social relationships across the lifespan.  Emphasizes communication as a means to facilitate conditions for development of positive relational outcomes. This is a writing intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in personal and social relationships
Facilitating positive relational outcomes through communication
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of communication theories and research findings

courseDescription: Focus on theory and research of communication processes in conflict episodes across social and personal relational contexts.  Applications of communication approaches to conflict management emphasized.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing communication patterns in conflict situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating communication strategies for conflict management

courseTitle: Listening to Self, Others, Nature and the Divine
courseDescription: The listening course introduces students to: 1) Practices for exploring and developing listening competencies, 2) Theoretical perspectives and models of listening, and 3) Research on listening. Practice, theory, and research are all integrated across the contexts of self, others, nature, and the divine.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of practice, theory, and research

courseDescription: Perspectives on nonviolent communication and peace are covered from the micro level (e.g., individual beliefs and worldviews) to interpersonal relationships (e.g., conflict management), groups (e.g., tribes, gangs), organizational systems (e.g., businesses, governments), and macro or global level (e.g., political relationships between nations).

This course investigates the history, types, characteristics, functions, and applications of love in everyday life, emphasizing the communication of altruistic/compassionate/agape love in four interrelated contexts: self, spirit, others, and creation. Theory, research, and applications of love will be explored within the spiritual, scientific, and dialogic (the conversation between science and spirit) perspectives.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing technology for expressing love online
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of love on mental well-being
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading by example in showing love to others
Creating a supportive environment for expressing love
Organizing community events centered around love

courseDescription: A survey of classic and contemporary theories and research of communication in family units, family relationships, and family interfacings with society.    The course emphasizes communication in the social construction of evolving 'family' realities as well as communication as means to facilitate conditions for development of positive domestic outcomes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Social construction of family realities analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Research design in family communication studies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of family communication theories

courseDescription: A survey of  theories and research of communication during childhood.  Emphasis is on children as developing communicators, their relationships, and their interactions with media.  Factors affecting  optimal development of children's communication and development of applications to enhance children's communication development are emphasized.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying factors influencing children's communication development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing strategies to enhance children's communication development
Leading projects focused on children's communication research

courseDescription: This course concentrates on the development and delivery of industry standard one-hour long TV scripts and the associated script 'bible.' Students will study sample scripts from broadcast TV programs and develop their own spec scripts. Cross-listed with THEA 430.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Receiving and incorporating feedback on scripts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to industry standards and requirements
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating with other TV production departments

courseDescription: This capstone course requires students to exhibit knowledge from  disciplinary curricula. Students will review an informed snapshot of current topics, methods and research within the communication discipline. Students will demonstrate communication competency through the development of a relevant final project (with required research).

This is an experiential style course in the art and business of documentary production in the hands-on, professional environment of WHRO, which operates Hampton Roads’ PBS affiliate TV station as well as two public radio stations. Students will be guided through the production of content for WHRO by an ODU faculty member and the WHRO staff. Cross-listed with THEA 439.
Technical and Digital Skills: Content creation for TV and radio stations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in a professional media environment

courseDescription: This course will seek to better understand the music industry.  To do this, the organization and operation of the modern music industry will be examined.  Issues of publishing, copyright and intellectual property and technology will also be examined.
Technical and Digital Skills: Intellectual property laws in the music industry
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with artists and industry professionals
Negotiation skills for music licensing agreements
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing copyright infringement cases in the music industry
Identifying solutions to music distribution challenges

courseDescription: This course explores the geographic dimensions of media, considering how issues of space and place intersect with the production and consumption of different forms of media. Employing semester-long cases that explore a range of mediated spaces from theme parks to television productions, students in the course will consider how spatiality shapes the cultural, economic, and creative dynamics of that production/experience.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of spatial media content
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in media space exploration
Leadership in spatial media case studies

courseDescription: A topical study of the major works of Spanish and Latin American film from Buneul to the present.  The course will explore many issues, including those related to gender, race, symbolism, and class struggle.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of film themes and symbolism

courseDescription: The first half of the 20th century was the most creative and destructive period in German and European history. Its rich cultural achievements included Viennese psychoanalytical theory of the turn of the century, Art Nouveau, German Expressionism, and the avant garde aesthetics of the Weimar Republic. Conversely, World War I and II exposed the cultural agony and human depravity of modern civilization. This course will trace these various aspects and developments in a variety of exemplary genres. Readings and discussions in German. (Cross-listed with WCS 445/WCS 545 and GER 445/GER 545)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting film analysis findings to the class
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting symbolism and themes in German cinema

courseDescription: A survey of the key methods used in critiquing various forms of human and mediated communication for the purpose of becoming more discerning consumers of public and mass mediated messages.  Analysis will include films, television, and radio programs, advertisements, newspapers, public discourses, speeches, and conversations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Critique methods for various forms of communication
Analysis of films, television, and radio programs
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Receiving and providing feedback on communication analyses
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Detecting manipulative techniques in media messages
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on communication analysis
Managing time effectively for analyzing various forms of communication

courseDescription: This course seeks to provide students with fundamental principles and practical techniques of directing the narrative fiction film: script development and analysis, production planning, shot composition and framing, and working with actors and crew.

This course focuses on legal and policy issues related to modern media systems and technologies, with an emphasis on legal considerations of electronic media.  Topics include First Amendment issues concerning news, programming, and advertising; station licensing; and challenges to traditional legal thought brought about by new technologies.  This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with digital rights management systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective written communication for legal documents
Clear verbal communication for presenting legal arguments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing complex legal issues related to electronic media
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on media law and policy

courseDescription: An examination of the rise of broadcast technology and world flow of information and entertainment.  Theory and policy issues of systems of broadcast ownership, access, regulation, programming, transborder, broadcasting and cultural imperialism and dominance of Western programming will be addressed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Awareness of cultural imperialism in media
Understanding of programming in media industry
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex media concepts
Collaboration with diverse teams in media projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of media ownership systems
Analyzing policy issues in media regulation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on media theory and policy
Leading teams in media production and analysis

courseDescription: This course is for students who are interested in the field of voice over for commercials, narration, industrials, animation, Internet, and gaming. Students will practice voicing copy using acting techniques, vocal techniques, building characters, and analyzing copy. Students will learn to select, edit and prepare copy for a future demo and learn to perform cold voice over auditions. This is a performance-oriented course that is a workout session each day. Crosslisted with THEA 453.
Technical and Digital Skills: Editing and preparing copy for demos
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Selecting appropriate copy for voice over
Critical evaluation of voice over scripts

courseDescription: Strategic communications is best learned by doing, including researching what has worked and what hasn't worked in strategies and tactics conducted by other professionals. This course will introduce students to a series of case studies organized thematically, grounding the knowledge gained in COMM 303 and allowing students to apply that knowledge to contemporary industries and cases of their own choosing.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Team collaboration in case study analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying successful tactics in case studies
Problem identification and resolution in communication strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in case study analysis
Leading group discussions on strategic communication topics
Time management for case study completion

courseDescription: A critical examination of the news industry as practiced in the printed press, network and cable television, magazines, the Internet, and alternative press.  Class examines the political economy of journalism, the sociology of journalistic practice, international news flows, ideological/political control of news, and mythological narrative forms within news.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing news coverage for bias and accuracy

courseDescription: Focuses on theories, research and applications of the social influence function of communication in a variety of organizational contexts. Examines traditional and nontraditional social influence theories and research as applied to organizational change.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding social influence theories in organizational contexts
Applying social influence theories to organizational change
Research methods in studying social influence in organizations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of social influence strategies in organizations
Collaborative decision-making in implementing social influence tactics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of social influence research in organizational settings
Problem-solving in applying social influence theories to organizational change
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading organizational change using social influence theories
Strategic planning for leveraging social influence in organizations

courseDescription: The foundation of any successful strategic communications, from marketing to public relations to advertising, is research. This course introduces students to secondary and primary research methods in an applied way, having students actually design and conduct full research studies for a client in the community. Students will discuss and conduct various forms of market research (situation, stakeholder, and competitor), explaining how it is integral to strategic thinking and responsible growth in order to directly prepare them for work in the field.

Social marketing, the process through which communications professionals attempt to introduce, reinforce, or augment social change through theories and practices of marketing, is a growing field with implications ranging from social entrepreneurship to international relations to community resiliency. This course will introduce the theories of social marketing, applying them through collaborations with a local organization or cause. Students will focus on a practical approach to constructing a brand through communication strategy and media tactics, and how those relate to constructing and maintaining the identity of a larger organization while also promoting social benefit.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Public speaking for promoting social change
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying target audience segments for campaigns
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for social marketing campaigns
Team coordination for social change initiatives
Strategic planning for brand identity and social benefit promotion

courseDescription: A survey of sport media and strategic communications. This course will expose students to the sport media industry, emphasizing the communications process in various mediums used to convey messages.  The internal and external publics involved in sport public relations will be examined, along with the steps involved in the process, particularly the strategic communication planning process.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Building relationships with internal and external publics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination for effective communication strategies

courseDescription: Designed to familiarize students with the fundamentals of beat reporting and its practice in the multimedia environment of 'converged' newsrooms. The course emphatically focuses on writing but also provides instruction on how the tools and techniques of multimedia platforms are used to enhance storytelling. Emphasis is also placed on accessing information through web-based resources and government documents. This is a writing intensive course.

This is primarily a sportswriting course in which students are introduced to various types and styles of sports stories that are representative of sports journalism as practiced in newspapers and magazines. The course also explores the role of sports in American society.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the impact of sports events on society
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Meeting deadlines for sports news coverage

courseDescription: Course includes discussion and practice of writing a variety of newspaper and magazine feature stories. Students will write and critique stories on people, places, businesses, trends, and issues. Assistance is given in the marketing of manuscripts.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with editors and other writers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the impact of a story on the audience
Critiquing and revising own work for improvement
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating with marketing teams for manuscript promotion

courseDescription: An examination of communication education theory and methodology via structured experiences and readings.  Students taking this course serve as teaching assistants for COMM 200S, which serves as a lab for practicing skills and techniques.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying teaching strategies for different learning styles
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions in lab sessions

courseDescription: An examination of world cinema as a technology, a business, an institution, and an art form from its inception to the present.  Emphasis is on the narrative fiction film, its technological and aesthetic development, economic organization, and socio-cultural context.  Representative classic and contemporary works will be screened and analyzed.  This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Screening and analyzing classic and contemporary films
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating economic organization of film industry

courseTitle: New Media Topics: Theories and Practices
courseDescription: This upper-division seminar investigates one or two particular emergent new media practices and theories.  The topics will be chosen at the discretion of the instructor but may include issues such as 'mobile media,' 'micro media and audiences,' and 'social media.'
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of new media concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of emerging new media practices
Analyzing new media trends and impacts

courseDescription: The role of television in the cultural, psychological, and economic life of America.  The structure and design of television programs; and the history and function of television in reinforcing or altering public perceptions of ideas, events, and people.  Major critical approaches are employed in examining television's social impact and global reach.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of television history and functions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting critical analysis of television content
Engaging in debates about public perceptions influenced by television
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying major critical approaches to analyze television's cultural impact
Identifying patterns in television program design
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on the role of television in society
Organizing research on television's economic influence
Collaborating with peers to explore diverse perspectives on television's effects

courseDescription: In the past two decades, reality television has become television's most replicated genre, documenting real people in 'real' situations across broadcast, cable, and streaming outlets. This class investigates the historical, cultural, and industrial logics that govern the rise of reality TV, exploring how the genre intersects with issues of race, gender, sexuality, and class, and asking students to apply their understanding of the genre to detailed analysis of its ongoing efforts to capture the complexities of everyday life.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of reality TV production techniques
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Editing footage to create engaging narratives
Resolving production challenges on the fly
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Budget management for reality TV projects

courseDescription: This course introduces students to the ways in which different media forms are used for advertising and marketing purposes.  Emphasis is on electronic media, though other approaches, such as direct marketing techniques and the increasing use of new media technologies for marketing, are also examined.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging with target audiences through media forms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing marketing data for performance evaluation
Identifying trends in media consumption patterns
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing media marketing campaigns
Coordinating cross-functional teams for promotional activities

courseDescription: An examination of American motion pictures as an art form, a business and an institution from inception to the present.  Primary attention is accorded to the narrative fiction film, its aesthetic and technological development, economic organization and social impact.  This course highlights the many connections between film history and American culture. This is a writing intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Participating in group discussions on film history
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the social impact of films on American culture
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively for writing-intensive assignments
Leading and organizing group projects related to film history

courseDescription: Students will continue the work performed in COMM 380 with more advanced proposals, research, and production work.

Students will explore storytelling for cinema through screenplay analysis, scene study, character development, narrative structure, and story development.  This upper-level, hands-on course applies a range of screenwriting principles to writing exercises, critique, and construction of the first half of a feature-length screenplay.

This is an intensive capstone course in film production.  Students experience pre-production, production, and post-production phases while creating a product to be entered in regional and national competitions.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with cast and crew
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to unexpected changes in production

courseDescription: This course is designed to extend students' knowledge of the media elements of strategic communications, from graphics to images to video. Students will discuss how to ground creative production in strategy for a client, how to focus on content and storytelling for a specific stakeholder, and how to create an extended, coherent plan using both creative and organizational goals. This is not intended to make students 'creative' but instead to show students how to design, direct, and manage the work that a media production team might do.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic alignment of creative work with organizational objectives

courseDescription: This course is designed to examine the conventions and meanings of various film and television genres within their broader aesthetic, socio-historical, cultural, and political contexts.  Each time the class is offered it will focus in depth on a different genre, such as the gangster, the Western, the musical, the comedy, science fiction, among others. Class may be repeated for credit as long as the genres are different.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of genre analysis findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying socio-historical influences on genre development

courseDescription: This course offers students an opportunity to collaborate on a faculty led project beyond the scope of typical classroom projects.  Students will execute an assigned duty for the duration of the semester.
Technical and Digital Skills: Editing software proficiency (e.g., Adobe Premiere, Final Cut Pro)

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students with advanced instruction in reporting, writing, and production for a television news program. Students will take on important roles in 15- and 30-minute news broadcasts and refine their skills in shooting and editing video. The goal of this course is to produce weekly news programs worthy of broadcast on local television. Students will receive significant experience in front of the camera as news, sports, and entertainment anchors/reporters as well as leadership positions in the television studio during the live broadcasts.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear and concise writing for news scripts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Troubleshooting technical issues during live broadcasts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating with news anchors, reporters, and production crew

courseTitle: Introduction to Critical Race and Media Studies
courseDescription: In this course, students examine how media culture - both historic and contemporary - contribute to the intersectional production of race in the United States. A guiding question will be:  How do media and popular culture - as texts, practices, industries, and sites of identity formation and pleasure - construct race?  Although students will theorize the politics of representation, they will also work to situate texts within a larger historic, political, and discursive context in order to assess the type of cultural work they perform.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of media analysis findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Contextualizing media texts within historical and political frameworks
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing research projects on media culture
Leading discussions on intersectional analysis of media and race

courseDescription: This course is designed to give an overview of contemporary scholarship on phenomena within the scope of interpersonal health communication.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying communication barriers in health contexts

courseDescription: In this course, students gain hands-on experience working with clients in an agency setting in which they not only work directly with clients, but are also given credit for learning new tools and software to build their portfolios. The first semester a student takes the course, they take a "junior" role where they are learning about and the process of working with their client. Repeat students take more senior roles, where they interface more extensively with the client and become leaders of teams of students and of bigger projects with more responsibility. The tools/software they learn will change each semester, as will their client, making the course a different experience each time and allowing them to grow into leadership positions that will transition well into project manager or creative director roles outside the university.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Handling bigger projects with more responsibility
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Transitioning into project manager or creative director roles

courseDescription: This course will delve into activism and social change from a local and global perspective in order to enhance students' perspectives of social change as it manifests via popular media and community action.

This course builds on the fundamentals learned in Cinematography 1, exploring advanced camera and lighting techniques primarily used in narrative cinema. Advanced cameras, grip, electric, and lighting equipment will be covered, exposing students to gear and practices beyond the scope of a standard student production. This is a production class.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of grip and electric equipment
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration on set with crew members
Ability to give and receive constructive feedback
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing lighting challenges and finding solutions
Adapting to unexpected changes during production
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team of crew members

courseDescription: This intensive course will bring students onto the set of a Feature Film Production, working crew positions as the film is shot. Cross-listed with THEA 493.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with cast and crew
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to unexpected changes in production schedule
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team of production assistants

courseDescription: This course is designed to help students enhance their personal and professional development through innovation guided by faculty members and professionals, while at the same time, meeting a critical need for Old Dominion University. Through a partnership with ODU's Office of Strategic Communication and Marketing, a select group of upper-level public relations, marketing or related discipline students will work, individually and in teams, as a "bureau" for the University's central marketing and communications office.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying target audience segments based on analytics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Delegating tasks effectively within a team
Leading cross-functional teams in PR initiatives

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly. These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly. These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Communication
courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor. Conferences and papers as appropriate.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Communication
courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor. Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Initiating and leading discussions in conferences

courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to the study of communication in cultural contexts, the purpose of which is to prepare students to live and work within an increasingly multicultural world.  This is accomplished by first defining and critically analyzing concepts of culture.  Throughout the semester, the course will investigate theories of culture and communication that address the development of cultural identity, intercultural communication competence, the role of verbal and nonverbal communication across cultures, the cultural composition of the U.S., and finally ethical communication and challenges in a globalized era.
Technical and Digital Skills: Verbal and nonverbal communication across cultures
Ethical communication in a globalized era
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Navigating cultural diversity in organizational settings

courseDescription: An overview of general and contextual theories of communication.  Focus is on the nature of communication theory, the role of theory in communication inquiry, and the relationships among theory, research, and practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing the role of theory in communication inquiry
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in discussions about communication theory
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theoretical knowledge to real-world communication scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on communication theory
Managing research projects related to communication theory

courseDescription: This course introduces students to the basic elements of public relations as it pertains to assisting organizations avoid, mitigate and recover from crisis situations.  Students will have the opportunity to both observe and participate in crisis communications situations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying communication gaps in crisis situations

courseDescription: This course introduces students to the multi-layered challenges associated with communication in the event of accidents, crises and natural disasters. In addition to incorporating basic elements of public relations as it pertains to assisting organizations avoid, mitigate and recover from external crisis situations, students will have the opportunity to both observe and participate in crafting multi-agency responses to these unplanned events.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing communication strategies for different crisis scenarios

courseDescription: A survey of classic and contemporary theories and research of communication in personal and social relationships across the lifespan.  Emphasizes communication as a means to facilitate conditions for development of positive relational outcomes.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing hypotheses based on research findings

courseDescription: Focus on theory and research of communication processes in conflict episodes across social and personal relational contexts.  Applications of communication approaches to conflict management are emphasized.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing communication patterns in conflict situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating communication strategies for conflict prevention
Team building activities for conflict resolution

courseDescription: Perspectives on nonviolent communication and peace are covered from the micro level (e.g., individual beliefs and worldviews) to interpersonal relationships (e.g., conflict management), groups (e.g., tribes, gangs), organizational systems (e.g., businesses, governments), and macro or global level (e.g., political relationships between nations).

This course investigates the history, types, characteristics, functions, and applications of love in everyday life, emphasizing the communication of altruistic/compassionate/agape love in four interrelated contexts: self, spirit, others, and creation. Theory, research, and applications of love will be explored within the spiritual, scientific, and dialogic (the conversation between science and spirit) perspectives.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing communication tools for expressing love
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Verbal and nonverbal communication of love
Resolving conflicts with love in mind
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing love theories and research findings
Evaluating the effectiveness of expressing love in various contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading by example in demonstrating love
Creating an environment conducive to expressing love
Organizing and prioritizing acts of love

courseDescription: A survey of classic and contemporary theories and research of communication in family units, family relationships, and family interfacings with society. The course emphasizes communication in the social construction of evolving "family" realities as well as communication as means to facilitate conditions for development of positive domestic outcomes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital communication tools for family interactions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying barriers to effective family communication

courseDescription: A survey of  theories and research of communication during childhood.  Emphasis is on children as developing communicators, their relationships, and their interactions with media.  Factors affecting  optimal development of children's communication and development of applications to enhance children's communication development are emphasized.
Technical and Digital Skills: Applying child development theories to digital communication
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting communication strategies for different age groups
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying barriers to children's communication development
Developing solutions to enhance children's communication skills
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Collaborating with educators and parents to support children's communication growth

courseDescription: A topical study of the major works of Spanish and Latin American film from Buneul to the present.  The course explores many issues, including those related to gender, race, symbolism, and class struggle.
Technical and Digital Skills: Spanish and Latin American film analysis
Knowledge of major works from Buneul to present
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion facilitation on gender, race, and class struggle in films
Collaboration with classmates on film projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of gender issues in films
Analyzing race representation in Hispanic cinema
Problem-solving related to class struggle themes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on film topics
Organizing film screenings and related events
Managing time effectively for film analysis and projects

courseDescription: The first half of the 20th century was the most creative and destructive period in German and European history. Its rich cultural achievements included Viennese psychoanalytical theory of the turn of the century, Art Nouveau, German Expressionism, and the avant garde aesthetics of the Weimar Republic. Conversely, World War I and II exposed the cultural agony and human depravity of modern civilization. This course will trace these various aspects and developments in a variety of exemplary genres. Readings and discussions in German. (Cross-listed with WCS 445/WCS 545 and GER 445/GER 545)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting film analysis findings in German
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical influences on film content
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group projects on film analysis

courseDescription: A survey of the key methods used in critiquing various forms of human and mediated communication for the purpose of becoming more discerning consumers of public and mass mediated messages.  Analysis will include films, television, and radio programs, advertisements, newspapers, public discourses, speeches, and conversations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing media content for underlying messages
