courseDescription: This course focuses on legal and policy issues related to modern media systems and technologies, with an emphasis on legal considerations of electronic media.  Subjects include First Amendment issues concerning news, programming, and advertising; station licensing; and challenges to traditional legal thought brought about by new technologies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of information security in media systems
Familiarity with legal considerations of electronic media technologies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate legal concepts effectively
Collaboration with media professionals on policy issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of legal issues in electronic media
Analyzing challenges to traditional legal thought brought by new technologies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in navigating complex legal and policy issues in media systems
Organizational skills in managing legal considerations in electronic media

courseDescription: An examination of the rise of broadcast technology and world flow of information and entertainment.  Theory and policy issues of systems of broadcast ownership, access, regulation, programming, transborder, broadcasting and cultural imperialism and dominance of Western programming will be addressed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of world flow of information
Familiarity with systems of broadcast ownership and regulation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of media theories and policies
Engaging in discussions on cultural imperialism
Ability to articulate the dominance of Western programming
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying key issues in media ownership and access
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on media theory and policy
Organizing research on global media trends
Facilitating debates on cultural influences in media

courseDescription: A critical examination of the news industry as practiced in the printed press, network and cable television, magazines, the Internet, and alternative press.  Class examines the political economy of journalism, the sociology of journalistic practice, international news flows, ideological/political control of news, and mythological narrative forms within news.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of news industry platforms (printed press, television, internet)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to critically analyze news content
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Effective time management for news research
Coordination of research efforts in journalism analysis

courseDescription: Focuses on theories, research and applications of the social influence function of communication in a variety of organizational contexts. Examines traditional and nontraditional social influence theories and research as applied to organizational change.
Technical and Digital Skills: Applying social influence theories in organizational contexts
Research skills in social influence theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing social influence strategies in organizations
Critical evaluation of social influence research in organizational change
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing social influence strategies in leadership roles

courseDescription: The foundation of any successful strategic communications, from marketing to public relations to advertising, is research. This course introduces students to secondary and primary research methods in an applied way, having students actually design and conduct full research studies for a client in the community. Students will discuss and conduct various forms of market research (situation, stakeholder, and competitor), explaining how it is integral to strategic thinking and responsible growth in order to directly prepare them for work in the field.

Social marketing, the process through which communications professionals attempt to introduce, reinforce, or augment social change through theories and practices of marketing, is a growing field with implications ranging from social entrepreneurship to international relations to community resiliency. This course will introduce the theories of social marketing, applying them through collaborations with a local organization or cause. Students will focus on a practical approach to constructing a brand through communication strategy and media tactics, and how those relate to constructing and maintaining the identity of a larger organization while also promoting social benefit.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation skills for promoting social benefit
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying target audience for marketing strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for social marketing campaigns
Team coordination in executing marketing plans
Strategic planning for brand identity maintenance

courseDescription: A survey of sport media and strategic communications. This course will expose students to the sport media industry, emphasizing the communications process in various mediums used to convey messages.  The internal and external publics involved in sport public relations will be examined, along with the steps involved in the process, particularly the strategic communication planning process.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of strategic communication planning process
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in sport media contexts
Public relations skills in sports industry
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing communication strategies in sport media
Strategic problem-solving for sport public relations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing internal and external publics in sport PR

courseDescription: An examination of world cinema as a technology, a business, an institution, and an art form from inception to the present.  Emphasis is on the narrative fiction film, its technological and aesthetic development, economic organization, and socio-cultural context.  Representative classic and contemporary works will be screened and analyzed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of socio-cultural impact on cinema
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing classic and contemporary films for themes and motifs

courseTitle: New Media Topics: Theories and Practices
courseDescription: This seminar investigates one or two particular emergent new media practices and theories.  The topics will be chosen at the discretion of the instructor but may include issues such as 'mobile media,' 'micro media and audiences,' and 'social media.'
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of new media concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of emerging new media practices
Analyzing audience engagement data in micro media
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on new media theories and practices
Organizing research on new media trends

courseDescription: This course introduces students to the ways in which different media forms are used for advertising and marketing purposes.  Emphasis is on electronic media, though other approaches, such as direct marketing techniques and the increasing use of new media technologies for marketing, are also examined.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in digital media campaigns
Client relationship management in marketing projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying target audience segments based on data analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for media marketing campaigns
Budget allocation and tracking for marketing initiatives

courseDescription: An examination of American motion pictures as an art form, a business and an institution from inception to the present.  Primary attention is accorded to the narrative fiction film, its technological and aesthetic development, economic organization and social impact.  This course highlights the many connections between film history and American culture.
Discussion/presentation topics range from production field work to post-production editing.  The final third of the semester will be devoted to compiling the rough footage in post production.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of footage for editing
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in decision-making for final video output

courseDescription: This course is designed to extend students' knowledge of the media elements of strategic communications, from graphics to images to video. Students will discuss how to ground creative production in strategy for a client, how to focus on content and storytelling for a specific stakeholder, and how to create an extended, coherent plan using both creative and organizational goals. This is not intended to make students 'creative' but instead to show students how to design, direct, and manage the work that a media production team might do.

This course is designed to examine the conventions and meanings of various film and television genres within their broader aesthetic, socio-historical, cultural, and political contexts. Each time the class is offered it will focus in depth on a different genre, such as the gangster, the Western, the musical, the comedy, science fiction, among others. Class may be repeated for credit as long as the genres are different.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective storytelling through film and television genres
Collaborative project management in film production
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Creative problem-solving in film and television production
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project planning and execution in film and television genres

courseDescription: This course offers students an opportunity to collaborate on a faculty led project beyond the scope of typical classroom projects. Students will execute an assigned duty for the duration of the semester.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to unexpected changes on set
Critical analysis of film techniques and storytelling methods

courseDescription: This course is designed to give an overview of contemporary scholarship on phenomena within the scope of interpersonal health communication.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective listening skills in health contexts
Empathy and rapport building with patients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying communication barriers in health interactions
Developing tailored communication strategies for diverse populations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination in healthcare communication projects

courseDescription: In this course, students gain hands-on experience working with clients in an agency setting in which they not only work directly with clients, but are also given credit for learning new tools and software to build their portfolios. The first semester a student takes the course, they take a "junior" role where they are learning about and the process of working with their client. Repeat students take more senior roles, where they interface more extensively with the client and become leaders of teams of students and of bigger projects with more responsibility. The tools/software they learn will change each semester, as will their client, making the course a different experience each time and allowing them to grow into leadership positions that will transition well into project manager or creative director roles outside the university.
Technical and Digital Skills: Learning new tools and software for portfolios
Using digital analytics tools for communication strategies
Adapting to different tools and software each semester
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to new project requirements each semester
Identifying project risks and finding solutions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading bigger projects with more responsibility
Being a project manager for client projects
Becoming a creative director for projects outside the university

courseDescription: This course will delve into activism and social change from a local and global perspective in order to enhance students' perspectives of social change as it manifests via popular media and community action.

The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly. These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly. These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Communication
courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor. Conferences and papers as appropriate.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Communication
courseDescription: Topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor. Conferences and papers as appropriate.

courseTitle: Intercultural Communication: History, Theory and Application
courseDescription: Students begin with an overview and then cover (1) past intercultural communication research, (2) the philosophical underpinning and ethics behind intercultural communication research, and (3) current developments in intercultural communication theory. They then address the application of intercultural communication theory in specific intercultural communication contexts (e.g. business, education, health and international travel).
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of communication theory in specific contexts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding past research in intercultural communication
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of intercultural communication theory
Evaluation of ethical implications in communication research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing strategies for effective intercultural communication

courseDescription: This course takes a developmental approach to the study of communication by exploring the culminating effects of communication as it evolves across our lifetime.  It encompasses all phases of life (birth-death) across interactions within family, work, social, health, and spiritual contexts.  The focus is on foundational and contemporary lifespan theories and research.

This class looks at emerging theories of new media and their transformative effects on industrial practices, news dissemination, cultural production, social interaction, and political engagement across the lifespan.  Students engage in ongoing theoretical debates and participate in various online endeavors that offer real world research opportunities.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing transformative effects of new media

courseDescription: Examines the role of various communication systems in enacting social change involving commercial, governmental and not-for-profit contexts.  Topics include persuasive techniques, community engagement, mobilizing large-scale social movements, and the political consequences of human and digital communication across the lifespan.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying key stakeholders in social change initiatives
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for social change initiatives

courseDescription: An overview of social scientific and qualitative methods used in lifespan development communication research.  Includes survey, experiment, observations, content and conversation analyses with an emphasis on developmental methods.  Approaches to studying communication of children, adolescents, and later life are included.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of research results to diverse audiences
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination for collaborative research projects

courseDescription: This class surveys the major methodological approaches available to critical communication researchers, such as semiology, structuralism, post-structuralism, neo-Marxism, and psychoanalysis, among others, within a cultural studies tradition.  Special attention is paid to various digital communication technologies and how they are utilized throughout the lifespan.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear and concise communication of complex ideas
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying patterns in digital communication practices

courseDescription: This course explores theories and research of communication in everyday relationships across the lifespan from early childhood relationships until relationships at the end of life.  Communication in personal and social relationships, within age cohorts (early childhood, adolescence, adulthood) are highlighted.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding communication technologies across different age groups
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication strategies for different age cohorts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing communication patterns in different life stages
Identifying barriers to effective communication across the lifespan
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading communication initiatives for diverse age groups

courseDescription: This course examines communication theories and research in light of the theories and research of positive psychology.  Topics include:  strengths-based communication theorizing, communication and happiness, positive communication functions, creative communication, and positive communication outcomes (health, wellness, peace, hope).
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of communication theories and research
Application of positive psychology principles in communication
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading by example in positive communication practices

courseDescription: This course examines the intersections of communication, geography, and food from lifespan and global perspectives. Topics to be covered include communication and cooking; dinner table talk; food and folk culture; victual rituals; the portrayals of food in media (e.g., film, television, CMC, print); the roles of race, class, and gender in food production/consumption; the commercialization of food; fast food and slow food; globalization vs. the 'locavore' movement; visualization and symbolic communication about food and nutrition; and market and supermarket geographies.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting market trends in food industry

courseTitle: Mediated Human Communication in the Digital Age
courseDescription: This course conceptualizes the relationship established by the processes of human communication that are mediated by new media technologies.  The course examines how such technologies affect social relationships, and how cultural values influence usage patterns of these technologies.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of technology on social relationships
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adapting to evolving digital communication trends

courseDescription: This course explores the theories, questions, claims and myths that have accompanied the rise of new communication technologies and electronically derived digital information that define the 'Electronic Revolution,' also known as the Information Society.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of communication technologies

courseDescription: The seminar surveys the relationship between communication and religion with an emphasis on theory, research and applications.  Topics may include the communication of religious beliefs/values via story, ritual, ceremony, worship, prayer and mediated communications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of media technologies in religious communication
Knowledge of digital platforms for religious communication
Media production skills for religious content creation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging with diverse audiences in religious communication settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of religious communication strategies
Research methods for studying communication of religious beliefs
Evaluation of the impact of mediated communications on religious practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination for collaborative worship projects

courseDescription: A structured work experience providing both a conceptual understanding and on-the-job training in some aspect of lifespan and digital communication. A journal, a final paper, a log of hours, a portfolio of work, and a satisfactory evaluation by wok supervisor and cooperating faculty member are required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with cooperating faculty member

courseDescription: This course examines the relationships among race, racial identity, and television.  Multiple scholarly traditions are used to examine the interactions among television tests, audiences and institution, and historical and contemporary race relations.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in scholarly discussions on race and television
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical and contemporary race relations in television
Critically evaluating television content through a racial lens
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on race and television
Organizing research projects related to television and race

courseTitle: Lifespan and Digital Communication Capstone Course
courseDescription: A capstone seminar for non-thesis students in their final semester to synthesize the relationships between lifespan and digital communication. Students will develop and complete a research paper or a digital communication project that they will present to a COMM graduate committee.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing lifespan data for communication purposes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a research or digital project team
Time management for completing a capstone project

courseDescription: This course is intended for students in the Master of Arts in Lifespan and Digital Communication program who choose the thesis option.  Course topics include:  developing a thesis proposal, thesis rules and regulations, the thesis committee, presenting and defending a thesis proposal, and acquiring the essential tools needed to write and successfully defend an MA thesis.
The study of selected topics designed to permit qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest in a seminar format which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for effective communication projects

courseTitle: Tutorial in Special Topics in Communication
courseDescription: Independent reading and study of a topic under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication through papers and conferences

courseDescription: This course is intended for students in the Master of Arts in Lifespan and Digital Communication program who choose the thesis option.  During the time a student is working on the MA thesis they must be enrolled in COMM 698, followed by COMM 699.

This course is intended for students in the Master of Arts in Lifespan and Digital Communication program who choose the thesis option.  During the time a student is working on the MA thesis they must be enrolled in COMM 698 followed by COMM 699.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem identification and resolution in thesis research

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide an overview of contemporary scholarship on phenomena within the scope of interpersonal health communication. Students will become familiar with fundamental communication processes that are involved in managing physical and mental health. Additionally, they will develop an awareness of how communication among friends, family members, professionals, and others influences people's well-being, and how, in turn, health and illness shape communication and relationship dynamics. Topics to be covered include patient identity and self-disclosure, social support, patient-provider communication, end-of-life care, and health education. Consistent with the goals of graduate education, students are expected to engage with the course content, exercise critical thinking skills, develop advanced reading and writing competencies, and develop a sense of practical applications of theory and research.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy building techniques in healthcare settings
Active listening skills in health conversations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying barriers to interpersonal health communication
Developing solutions for miscommunication in healthcare
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating multidisciplinary healthcare teams for effective communication

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics in communication studies will be covered in such a way as to permit small groups of qualified students to study subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.
Technical and Digital Skills: Advanced research methods in communication studies
Specialized software applications for data analysis in communication research
Digital media production tools for communication studies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective group collaboration in research projects
Oral presentation skills for communicating research findings
Writing and editing skills for academic publications in communication studies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of scholarly literature in communication studies
Identifying research gaps and formulating research questions
Data interpretation and synthesis for communication research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for research initiatives in communication studies
Team coordination and delegation in research projects
Leadership in academic discussions and debates on communication topics

courseDescription: Independent research directed by professors/faculty members examining communication topics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis using SPSS or NVivo

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics in communication studies are covered in such a way as to permit small groups of qualified students to study subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.
Independent research directed by professors/faculty members examining communication topics.

This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Root cause analysis of technical issues
